metadata.title: Introduction to DVC: Data Version Control Tool for Machine Learning Projects | by Khuyen Tran | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Introduction to DVC: DataVersion Control Tool for Machine Learning Projects
metadata.description: As a data scientist, you might experiment with different combinations of code, data, and models. Thus, it is important to version your code, data, and model so that you can reproduce past…

all_paragraphs: As a data scientist, you might experiment with different combinations of code, data, and models. Thus, it is important to version your code, data, and model so that you can reproduce past experiments.
But how do you version your code, data, and models?
Git is a great platform for controlling the version of your code, but it is not ideal to version your data and model for two reasons:

Wouldn’t it be nice if you can store your data in your favorite storage services such as Amazon S3, Google Drive, Google Cloud Storage, or your own local machine while still being able to version control your data? That is when DVC comes in handy.

DVC is a system for data version control. It is essentially like Git but is used for data. With DVC, you can keep the information about different versions of your data in Git while storing your original data somewhere else.
Better yet, DVC syntax is just like Git! If you already know Git, learning DVC is a breeze.
To understand how to use DVC, let’s start with an example. I will use my repository as an example of this article. You can follow along by cloning the repository.
Start with installing the package with pip
Find the instruction on more ways to install DVC here.
After DVC is installed, in a Git project, initialize it by running
.dvc/.gitignore and .dvc/config is created. Commit this change with
Here is the structure of my data directory
To start tracking a file or directory, use dvc add
To track the data directory, use

The information of the added file or directory will be stored in .dvc file nameddata.dvc . This is a small text file that stores information on how to access the original data but not the original data itself.
Since the size of this text file is small, it can be versioned like source code with Git.
Now simply commit the dvcfile as you would with source code. Make sure to add data to .gitignore beforehand to avoid committing the data.
Cool! Now we created a file to store the information about the original data. The next step is to figure out where to store the data
Just like how we usegit add remote to store the URL of the remote repository, we also want to use dvc remote add to store the location of the remote storage.

DVC allows us to store our data on Google Drive, Amazon S3, Azure Blob Storage, Google Cloud Storage, Aliyun OSS, SSH, HDFS, and HTTP. Since I assume everybody has Google Drive, let’s learn how to store our data on Google Drive
Start with creating a folder on Google Drive
Once we created a folder, our link will be something like this https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1ynNBbT-4J0ida0eKYQqZZbC93juUUbVH
Simply add that link to DVC to store the location of the remote storage
-d stands for default. The information about the storage will be saved under .dvc/config
Now simply commit the config file
And push the data to Google Drive
That’s it! Now all of the data is pushed to Google Drive. Checkoutdvc remote add for more ways to store your data in other storage services.
To push the change we have committed so far to our remote repository, type
Your data is stored somewhere safe. But now you or your teammates want to access the data, what should you or your teammates do?
It’s straight forward. Just use git pull to pull the change in code like you normally do. Now you have the .dvc file in your local directory.
To retrieve the data, simply type
to pull the data from the remote storage. That’s it!
If you are following in tutorial and you still have the data directory in your local machine, delete it to see how the dvc pullcan retrieve your data from remote storage.
It is straight forward, isn’t it?

The whole point of using DVC is that we can switch between different versions of our data. So how exactly can we do that? Again, just like how we switch between different versions of our code with Git, use dvc checkout to switch between different versions of our data
For example, if we want to switch to the previous version of the data, type
Now when the data reverts to the previous version, use
Basically, we switch to another version of our code with git chechout. dvc checkout restores the corresponding versions of the .dvc files and directories from .dvc/cacheto the workspace.

Congratulations! You have just learned about how to control different versions of your data with DVC! If you are still hesitant to use DVC for your data science project, it is time to give it a try. The syntax is similar to Git. Use:
You and your teammates will be happy to save the changes in your data in Git with simple command lines like above while storing your data in your favorite storage service!
Feel free to play with the code in this article here
I like to write about basic data science concepts and play with different algorithms and data science tools. You could connect with me on LinkedIn and Twitter.
Star this repo if you want to check out the codes for all of the articles I have written. Follow me on Medium to stay informed with my latest data science articles like these:
